sen.e: Due to the progression of seclusionism by Edo Bakufu, the Shuinsen with the official approval of bakufu became hard to travel abroad, and there was the First Seclusion Order that forbid the foreign and returning trips other than ships carrying the messages of roju (member of shogun's council of elders) in 1633 and the Third Seclusion Order was given out that forbid all Japanese foreign travel and returning trip to Japan in 1635 that ended the Shuinsen trading.

Due to the progression of seclusionism by Edo Bakufu, it became more difficult for the Shuinsen with the official approval of bakufu to travel abroad, and there was the First Seclusion Order that forbid the foreign and returning trips other than ships carrying the messages of roju (member of shogun's council of elders) in 1633 and the Third Seclusion Order was given out that forbid all Japanese foreign travel and returning trip to Japan in 1635 that ended the Shuinsen trading.

It became increasingly more difficult even for government-certified Shuinsen ships to travel to other countries due to the isolationist policy of the shogunate government; in 1633, the First Seclusion Order, which forbade all ships other that those carrying official letters of the shogunate government to visit or return from other countries, was issued; and in 1935, the Third Seclusion Order, which forbade all Japanese to travel to or return from other countries, was issued, bringing an end to Shuinsen trade.
